title-group.article-title: Intrauterine Hormone Effects on Tooth Dimensions

article-meta.aff: 1School of Dentistry, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia, 5005
2Queen Mary University of London, London, UK
3International Collaborating Network in Oro-facial Genetics and Development

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 International & American Associations for Dental Research
permissions.copyright-holder: International & American Associations for Dental Research

abstract.p: The human dentition is a complex adaptive system that is influenced by genetic, epigenetic, and environmental factors. Within this system, is sexual dimorphism related to the growth promotion of the Y chromosome, or to hormonal influences, or both? This study is the first to investigate both primary and permanent tooth sizes in females from opposite-sex dizygotic (DZOS) twin pairs compared with females from dizygotic same-sex (DZSS) and monozygotic (MZ) twin pairs to indicate the influence of intrauterine male hormone, including the initial testosterone surge, on dental development. Serial dental models of the primary, mixed, and permanent dentitions of 134 females from DZOS, DZSS, and MZ twins were examined. Mesiodistal, buccolingual, crown height, and intercuspal dimensions of all primary teeth and selected permanent teeth were determined by image analysis. Univariate and multivariate analyses showed statistically significantly larger crown size in DZOS females in both dentitions, with the crown height dimensions displaying the greatest increase in size. These findings strongly support the Twin Testosterone Transfer (TTT) hypothesis. We propose that the growth-promoting effects of the Y chromosome and intrauterine male hormone levels influence different tooth dimensions and contribute differentially to the sexual dimorphism of human teeth.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The human dentition is a complex adaptive system that is influenced by genetic, epigenetic, and environmental factors (Brook, 2009; Brook and O’Donnell, 2012; Townsend et al., 2012a). Sexual dimorphism of the teeth has been considered by some authors to relate mainly to the growth-promoting effects of the Y chromosome (Guatelli-Steinberg et al., 2008; Alvesalo, 2009), while others have suggested that hormonal influences during tooth development are also important (Dempsey et al., 1999).

In humans, around week 6 of gestation, the Sry gene on the Y chromosome initiates testicular differentiation in the male. An intrauterine surge of testosterone occurs soon after, at around 7 to 9 weeks of gestation, with high levels from weeks 10 to 24 in utero, peaking around week 14 (Reyes et al., 1974; Knickmeyer and Baron-Cohen, 2006; Tapp et al., 2011). Subsequent higher testosterone levels in umbilical cord blood at birth in males, when compared with females, are thought to reflect the fetal circulation levels during late gestation (Whitehouse et al., 2012).

Although amniocentesis provides the most accurate measure of fetal androgen exposure currently available (Cohen-Bendahan et al., 2005), it is invasive and performed only where there is a medical justification (Tapp et al., 2011). An alternative approach is to use the Twin Testosterone Transfer hypothesis (TTT), which is based on studies demonstrating that androgens can diffuse from a male to a female fetus in utero, influencing behavioral and morphological traits (Miller, 1994; Miller and Martin, 1995; Peper et al., 2009; Tapp et al., 2011). This TTT hypothesis can be investigated by comparing characteristically dimorphic phenotypes in females from opposite-sex dizygotic twin pairs (DZOS) with those in females from dizygotic same-sex twin pairs (DZSS) and females from monozygotic twin pairs (MZ).

Our study is the first to investigate several dental crown dimensions in both the primary and the permanent dentitions of females from DZOS, DZSS, and MZ twin pairs as an indication of probable influence of intrauterine male hormone levels on dental development. The hypothesis is that females from DZOS twin pairs will have larger tooth crown dimensions than females from either DZSS or MZ pairs, relating to intrauterine hormone diffusion.

sec.title: Materials & methods
sec.p: Serial dental casts of the primary, mixed, and permanent dentitions were obtained in a longitudinal study of 134 females between the ages of 4 and 16 yrs from 43 dizygotic opposite-sex (DZOS), 39 dizygotic same-sex (DZSS), and 52 monozygotic (MZ) twin pairs. This ongoing study of dentofacial development of Australian twins and their families is being undertaken in the School of Dentistry at the University of Adelaide (Townsend et al., 2012b). One co-twin from each pair of MZ and DZSS twins was randomly selected, to prevent bias from inclusion of tooth size data from both co-twins. All participants were of European ancestry, with no relevant medical and dental history. Zygosity was determined by analysis of 10 highly polymorphic DNA markers extracted from cheek cells; the probability of dizygosity given concordance was less than 1% (Hughes et al., 2007).

Measurements were obtained for all primary teeth and for permanent central incisors, mandibular lateral incisors, canines, second premolars, and first and second molars. The dental casts were coded prior to measurement so that the operator was blinded to the zygosity and sex of the twins. Teeth excluded were: permanent maxillary lateral incisors, because of their greater variability; first premolars, because previously in this sample no difference was found greater than 0.1 mm for MD and BL dimensions between males and females for these teeth; and third molars, because impressions were obtained before eruption of these teeth. Teeth displaying wear, caries, or restorations, or which were not fully erupted, were excluded. Maximum mesiodistal (MD) crown dimensions, buccolingual or labiolingual (BL) crown dimensions, crown height (CH) dimensions, and intercuspal distances, that is, the distances between the cusp tips (IC), were measured by means of a 2D image analysis system, previously validated for tooth size determination (Brook et al., 1999, 2005). Dimensions were recorded to the nearest 0.01 mm.

Univariate and multivariate statistical analyses were used. Analyses were based on measurement data represented to 2 decimal places, but mean values were truncated to 1 decimal place for tabular presentation. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was applied with Proc GLM in SAS/STAT software to the different tooth crown dimensions (MD, BL, CH, and IC) of individual teeth in both dentitions, to facilitate comparisons between DZOS females and DZSS and MZ female twins, to search for any patterns or trends, and to quantify associations with the formation of each tooth dimension. These analyses included post hoc pair-wise zygosity comparisons, with the Tukey-Kramer adjustment for multiple comparisons, with statistical significance set at p < .05.

Multivariate (MANOVA) analysis was performed with Proc GLM in SAS/STAT software, with the different tooth crown dimensions investigated simultaneously. Independent variables within the model included zygosities (MZ, DZSS, and DZOS), dentitions (primary and permanent), quadrant (UL, UR, LL, LR), and tooth. Twin ID was fitted as a random effect within the model to account for possible correlations between measurements from the same individual. The final model after exclusion of non-significant higher order interactions was as follows:

Post hoc pair-wise zygosity comparisons, with the Tukey-Kramer adjustment for multiple comparisons, were also made. This model examined dimensional variation down to the level of an individual tooth. The analysis was performed for all MD, BL, and CH crown dimensions; IC dimensions were excluded from the multivariate analyses, because of larger numbers of missing values resulting from tooth wear.

sec.title: Validation - Errors of the Study
sec.p: Double determination analysis was performed for all variables, dentitions, and zygosities studied. Paired t tests were used to assess systematic errors of the method, while Dahlberg statistics were used to assess random errors of measurement (Dahlberg, 1940). No evidence of systematic errors was found, and random errors were less than 10% of observed variance.

sec.title: Univariate Analyses
sec.p: Sample sizes were less than the number of participants for most variables, because some participants did not have full primary or permanent dentitions when impressions were obtained, or because measurements could not be obtained for some teeth. Table 1 presents MD and BL dimensions, Table 2 CH dimensions, and Table 3 IC dimensions for females from DZOS twin pairs and females from MZ and DZSS twin pairs for the right side.

caption.p: Comparison of Mesiodistal (MD) and Buccolingual (BL) Dimensions in the Primary and Permanent Dentitions between Females from DZOS, DZSS, and MZ Twin Pairs

fn.p: i1 = primary central incisor; i2 = primary lateral incisor; c = primary canine; m1 = primary first molar; m2 = primary second molar; I1 = permanent central incisor; I2 = permanent lateral incisor; C = permanent canine; PM2 = permanent second premolar; M1 = permanent first molar; M2 = permanent second molar; n = sample size; mean = mean values; SD = standard deviation; (aDZOS ≠ DZSS, bDZOS ≠ MZ, cDZSS ≠ MZ, + Levene’s test, p < .05); shading denotes direction of difference, regardless of level of significance obtained (red shading, DZOS > DZSS/MZ; yellow shading, DZOS = DZSS/MZ; green shading, DZOS < DZSS/MZ).

caption.p: Comparison of Crown Height (CH) Dimensions in the Primary and Permanent Dentitions between Females from DZOS, DZSS, and MZ Twin Pairs

fn.p: i1 = primary central incisor; i2 = primary lateral incisor; c = primary canine; m1 = primary first molar; m2 = primary second molar; I1 = permanent central incisor; I2 = permanent lateral incisor; C = permanent canine; PM2 = permanent second premolar; M1 = permanent first molar; M2 = permanent second molar; n = sample size; mean = mean values; SD = standard deviation; (aDZOS ≠ DZSS, bDZOS ≠ MZ, cDZSS ≠ MZ, + Levene’s test, p < .05); shading denotes direction of difference, regardless of level of significance obtained (red, DZOS>DZSS/MZ; yellow, DZOS = DZSS/MZ; green, DZOS < DZSS/MZ).

caption.p: Comparison of Intercuspal (IC) Dimensions in the Primary and Permanent Dentitions between Females from DZOS, DZSS, and MZ Twin Pairs

fn.p: m1 = primary first molar; m2 = primary second molar; PM2 = permanent second premolar; M1 = permanent first molar; M2 = permanent second molar; (ic) = bucco-lingual intercuspal dimension in primary first molars; (ic1) = primary mesiobuccal-mesiolingual intercuspal dimension; (ic2) = primary mesiobuccal-distobuccal intercuspal dimension; (ic3) = primary distobuccal-distolingual intercuspal dimension; (ic4) = primary mesiolingual-distolingual intercuspal dimension; (IC) = permanent bucco-lingual intercuspal dimension; (IC1) = permanent mesiobuccal-mesiolingual intercuspal dimension; (IC2) = permanent mesiobuccal-distobuccal intercuspal dimension; (IC3) = permanent distobuccal-distolingual intercuspal dimension; (IC4) = permanent mesiolingual-distolingual intercuspal dimension; n = sample size; mean = mean values; SD = standard deviation. (aDZOS ≠ DZSS, bDZOS ≠ MZ, cDZSS ≠ MZ, + Levene’s test, p < .05); shading denotes direction of difference, regardless of level of significance obtained (red, DZOS>DZSS/MZ; yellow, DZOS = DZSS/MZ; green, DZOS < DZSS/MZ).

sec.p: Overall, DZOS females displayed larger mean values for MD, BL, and CH dimensions in the primary and permanent dentitions compared with DZSS and MZ female twins (red shading in tables), with some teeth displaying statistically significant differences between DZOS females and DZSS females, as well as between DZOS females and MZ females, especially for BL and CH dimensions (Tables 1 and 2). However, the same pattern was not evident for IC dimensions among DZOS, DZSS, and MZ female twins (Table 3).

Although the patterns of differences varied across dentitions, there was a definite trend for females from DZOS pairs to display larger tooth dimensions than females from MZ pairs, except for IC dimensions. The early-forming IC dimensions displayed a different pattern compared with the later-forming dimensions, since more similar mean values were found in the primary dentition (yellow shading in tables), while the permanent dentition displayed a combination of smaller mean values (green shading) and equal mean values (yellow shading). Average percentage increases in tooth size were greatest for crown height dimensions (around 4-6%), followed by buccolingual dimensions (around 2-2.5%), then mesiodistal dimensions (around 1-2%), and were least for intercuspal dimensions (around 0-1%). Male results are not considered in this paper, since they are not part of the research question, but a previous study found no systematic trends for altered tooth size in either dentition or for any of the crown dimensions between different male twin groups (Ribeiro, 2012).

sec.title: Multivariate Analysis
sec.p: MANOVA removes samples with missing values list-wise. Of 5,670 possible observations, 3,678 observations were available concurrently for analysis of MD, BL, and CH dimensions. Data were assumed to be missing at random. The multivariate model explained a large proportion of the observed variation in all dimensions (MD, 97%; BL, 98%; CH, 90%). Multivariate test statistics for effects in the model on tooth dimensions were all significant (p < .0001). Fig. A presents least-squares mean values (in mm) and standard errors (SE) for MD, BL, and CH dimensions in the primary and permanent dentitions of MZ, DZSS, and DZOS female twins. Examination of least-squares means revealed that, on a whole-dentition basis, the DZOS females had significantly larger values for all dimensions in both dentitions when compared with the MZ females, and for all dimensions except primary MD when compared with the DZSS females. The DZSS and MZ females were similar for all dimensions except primary MD. There was a trend for the OS-SS female differences to increase MD < BL < CH in both dentitions. When scaled relative to tooth size, the differences between SS and OS twins were ~ MD 0.8%; BL 1.7%; CH 3.0% in the primary dentition and ~ MD 1.8%; BL 2.3%; CH 3.5% in the permanent dentition.

caption.p: (A) Differences of least-squares mean values (in mm) in DZSS and MZ females compared with DZOS females [for mesiodistal (MD), buccolingual (BL), and crown height (CH) dimensions]. Standard errors in brackets. Negative values indicate that values for DZSS and MZ females are smaller than those for DZOS females. There is no bar for primary MD dimensions in DZSS females because the mean value for DZSS females was equal to that for DZOS females. (B) The tooth germ stages of all teeth except third molars (dates from Kitamura, 1989) and the testosterone levels (from Tapp et al., 2011) set against fetal age (Reyes et al., 1974; Knickmeyer and Baron-Cohen, 2006).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The current study is the first to investigate possible hormonal effects on various crown dimensions of both human primary and permanent teeth in the same individuals. This is important, since all the primary teeth are developing during the intrauterine surge of testosterone levels, while the earliest permanent teeth are initiated at the end of this surge; the soft-tissue morphogenetic stages of the permanent teeth, except the third molar, largely occur during the testosterone levels that continue until birth (Fig., B). This is also the first study of hormonal effect to use image analysis of several dental phenotypes, including crown heights and intercuspal distances, thereby providing increased opportunities for validation. Intercuspal dimensions of the crown are the first dimensions to develop during odontogenesis; mesiodistal dimensions are established when tooth crown formation reaches its greatest convexity in size; buccolingual dimensions are finalized later; and crown height dimensions are completed when the dental crown is fully formed and calcification of the root commences (Nanci, 2003).

Dizygotic opposite sex twin pairs provide a unique model for analysis of the influence of sex hormones on dental crown size, since males and females from DZOS twins develop under different concentrations of sex hormones from same-sex twins (Miller, 1994). The highly significant differences in tooth size found in this study between DZOS females, compared with either DZSS or MZ females, were evident in both dentitions, but the differences were smaller in the primary dentition. This may be due to at least three factors: (1) The initiation of some primary tooth germs occurs before male hormones start to be released by the male co-twin testis, and, by the time the male hormones reach their peak around 14 wks post-conception, most of the primary teeth are close to or have commenced calcification; (2) the developmental processes in the primary dentition occur within a shorter period of time than the permanent dentition, and, therefore, this dentition has shorter exposure to intrauterine male hormones; and (3) the first-formed permanent teeth are initiated and commence morphogenesis around 16 wks post-conception and undertake a longer period of development before calcification (Fig., B; Kitamura, 1989), and intrauterine androgens may exert organizational effects on physical and behavioral development beyond birth, having initiated intracellular changes (Tapp et al., 2011; Whitehouse et al., 2012).

Alvesalo (2009) reviewed the influence of the sex chromosomes on dental growth in patients with chromosomal aneuploidies, showing that both X and Y chromosomes are involved in dental growth. The Y chromosome promotes the development of both enamel and dentin, while the X chromosome influences the development of enamel. The direct effect of the Y chromosome on tooth size, illustrated by the larger teeth in XYY males compared with those in XY males, may be due to specific genes or the effect of heterochromatin on cellular activity (Townsend, 1985). An additional X chromosome as in 47XXY, Klinefelter syndrome males has its greatest effect on IC dimensions and least on BL dimensions (Townsend and Alvesalo, 1999). This is in interesting contrast to our present findings for hormonal effects. In 45XO, Turner syndrome females, the teeth are smaller than in control individuals for all variables (Horrocks et al., 2009).

Guatelli-Steinberg et al. (2008) examined sexual dimorphism, using the enamel initiation and formation times reported by Reid and Dean (2006), and mesiodistal dimensions of permanent tooth size. They suggested that sexual dimorphism in the human dentition is mainly related to the growth-promoting effect of the Y chromosome, and that sex hormones have either no effect or only a minor influence. However, their predictions are based on post-natal testosterone levels and, in our view, underestimated the importance of intrauterine levels of male hormone. Since all teeth except third molars start to form and pass through stages of morphogenesis and differentiation in utero (Fig., B) (Nanci, 2003; Lesot and Brook, 2009), consideration of intrauterine testosterone levels is essential. Although sex chromosomes may determine a substantial amount of the size variation between male and female dentitions, our findings indicate that testosterone levels are also influential. A proposed mechanism for this effect is that testosterone is bound by androgen receptors in the cytoplasm of cells. This complex can then enter the nucleus, where it bonds to DNA and affects transcription (Whitehouse et al., 2012). Once primed in this way, the testosterone effect could continue when the elevated levels are no longer present.

In conclusion, our results provide strong support for the Twin Testosterone Transfer hypothesis by showing that females from DZOS twin pairs have significantly larger teeth than female MZ and DZSS twins. Moreover, dimensions such as CH, which have had longer exposure to intrauterine male hormone, show larger differences than dimensions which are established early on, such as intercuspal distances. We suggest that both the direct effects of the sex chromosomes and intrauterine male hormone levels are factors in tooth size sexual dimorphism and are components in the complex adaptive system of dental development involving genetic, epigenetic, and environmental factors, with the sex chromosomes and male hormones having their main effects on different dimensions of crown morphology.

ack.p: We thank the participants, and we also thank Dr. Richard Smith for support in developing the image analysis system in Adelaide and Dr. Tom Coxon for assistance with double determinations. The data analysis for this paper was generated with SAS/STAT software, Version 9.2, of the SAS System for Windows. Copyright 2012, SAS Institute, Inc.
